## Automation is key

###This is why we use `porder`, a command line interface:

### porder uses the [v2 Planet API](https://developers.planet.com/docs/orders/reference/)
### [porder description](https://samapriyaroy.medium.com/order-up-using-and-building-with-planet-s-new-ordersv2-api-ba2fe14eac8e)
### [porder github](https://github.com/tyson-swetnam/porder)



---
## Getting porder installed
### You should have Python3 installed with Anaconda
### First run "pip install planet"  (also config, requests)
### Then run "pip install porder"

---
## Running porder
### you need to log-in first
### run "planet init" in terminal, and log-in with your Planet account (with educational license)
### check your image quota "porder quota"
### help is "porder -h"

## Searching
### Example
```
porder idlist --input '/Users/michaelcecil/Rprojects/geog287387_s/materials/data/whittier/whittier_aoi/whittier_aoi.geojson' --start '2020-06-01' --end '2020-09-30' --item 'PSOrthoTile' --asset 'analytic_sr'  --outfile '/Users/michaelcecil/Downloads/whittier_2020_sr.csv' --overlap '100' --filters 'range:view_angle:-3:3' 'range:clear_percent:70:100' 'string:ground_control:True' 'string:quality_category:standard'
```
---
## 1. Searching
### the "input" argument is used to filter to an AOI (use this!! otherwise your quota will run out)
### "input" needs to be .geojson file type, one standard format for spatial data. [More info here](https://macwright.com/2015/03/23/geojson-second-bite.html)
### matching files will be saved to "outfile" (.csv)

### A look at our Planet results

```{r, eval = FALSE, echo = FALSE}
library(raster)
p <- dir("/Users/michaelcecil/Rprojects/geog287387_s/materials/data/whittier/porder_download", pattern = "SR_clip.tif", full.names = TRUE)

rl <- lapply(p, function(x) {
  b <- raster::brick(x)
  b / cellStats(b, max)
})

# plot
for(i in 1:length(rl)) {
  b <- rl[[i]]
  nm <- gsub("_aoi.tif", "", basename(p[i]))
  plot(as(extent(b), "SpatialPolygons"), lty = 0, axes = FALSE)
  plotRGB(b[[c(4,3,2)]], axes = FALSE, scale = 1, add = TRUE)
  mtext(nm, side = 3, line = 0, cex = 0.8, col = "white")
}
```

### UDM-2 masking
### let's calulate the percent of each image that is "clear"
### 
```{r, eval = FALSE, echo = FALSE}

p_udm2 <- dir("/Users/michaelcecil/Rprojects/geog287387_s/materials/data/whittier/porder_download/", pattern = "udm2", full.names = TRUE)

rl_udm2 <- lapply(p_udm2, function(x) {
  b <- raster::brick(x)
})



```

```{r, eval = FALSE, echo = FALSE}
##clearness plots
for(i in 1:length(rl_udm2)) {
  b <- rl_udm2[[i]]
  nm <- gsub("_aoi.tif", "", basename(p[i]))
  plot(as(extent(b), "SpatialPolygons"), lty = 0, axes = FALSE)
  raster::plot(b[[c(1)]], axes = FALSE, scale = 1, add = TRUE)
  mtext(nm, side = 3, line = 0, cex = 0.8, col = "white")
}

```


---
```{r, eval = FALSE, echo = FALSE}
##pct clear
pct_clear <- sapply(1:length(rl_udm2), function(x){
  b <- rl_udm2[[x]]  ## get the UDM2 raster brick in spot x, x going from 1 to 84
  clear_raster <- b[[1]] ### get first band, clearness
  pct_clear <- cellStats(clear_raster, stat = 'mean')
})

```


```{r, eval = FALSE, echo = FALSE}

good_images <- (pct_clear > 0.90)

rl_filtered <- rl[good_images]

# plot
for(i in 1:length(rl_filtered)) {
  b <- rl_filtered[[i]]
  nm <- gsub("_aoi.tif", "", basename(p[i]))
  plot(as(extent(b), "SpatialPolygons"), lty = 0, axes = FALSE)
  plotRGB(b[[c(3,2,1)]], axes = FALSE, scale = 1, add = TRUE)
  mtext(nm, side = 3, line = 0, cex = 0.8, col = "white")
}
```

### GCVI => LAI

GCVI = (NIR / GRN) â€“ 1

GCVI = 1.4 * LAI^1.03 + 0.93

LAI = ((GCVI - 0.93) / 1.4)^(1 / 1.03)

```{r, eval = FALSE}
## LAI plots
for(i in 1:length(rl_filtered)) {
  b <- rl_filtered[[i]]
  gcvi <- b[[4]] / b[[1]] - 1
  gcvi <- max(gcvi, 0.93)
  lai <- ((gcvi - 0.93) / 1.4)^(1 / 1.03)
  nm <- gsub("_aoi.tif", "", basename(p[i]))
  plot(as(extent(lai), "SpatialPolygons"), lty = 0, axes = FALSE)
  plot(lai, axes = FALSE, add = TRUE, zlim = c(0, 5))#, 
       #axis.args = list(col = "white", col.axis = "white"))
  mtext(nm, side = 3, line = 0, cex = 0.8)#, col = "white")
}
```
